description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at AIDS Daily-- Investigators publish new report on HIV/AIDS. We assessed the prevalence of PDR and treatment outcomes among adults living with HIV-1 in Lilongwe, Malawi.”. Funders for this research include Hector Stiftung, Weinheim, Germany.
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at AIDS Daily \--
Investigators publish new report on HIV/AIDS. According to news reporting
originating from the University Hospital Heidelberg by NewsRx correspondents,
research stated, "Pre-treatment drug resistance (PDR) among antiretroviral
drug-naive people living with HIV (PLHIV) represents an important indicator
for the risk of treatment failure and the spread of drug resistant HIV
variants. We assessed the prevalence of PDR and treatment outcomes among
adults living with HIV-1 in Lilongwe, Malawi."

Funders for this research include Hector Stiftung, Weinheim , Germany.

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from University
Hospital Heidelberg: "We selected 200 participants at random from the
Lighthouse Tenofovir Cohort Study (LighTen). Serum samples were drawn prior to
treatment initiation in 2014 and 2015, frozen, and later analyzed for the
presence of HIV-1 drug resistance mutations. Amplicons were sequenced and
interpreted by Stanford HIVdb interpretation algorithm 8.4. We assessed
treatment outcomes by evaluating clinical outcome and viral suppression at the
end of the follow-up period in October 2019. PDR testing was successful in 197
of 200 samples. The overall NNRTI- PDR prevalence was 13.7% (27/197). The
prevalence of intermediate or high level NNRTI- PDR was 11.2% (22/197). The
most common mutation was K103N (5.6%, 11/197), followed by Y181C (3.6%,
7/197). In one case, we detected an NRTI resistance mutation (M184V), in
combination with multiple NNRTI resistance mutations. All HIV-1 isolates
analyzed were of subtype C. Of the 27 patients with NNRTI- PDR, 9 were still
alive, on ART, and virally suppressed at the end of follow-up."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The prevalence of
NNRTI- PDR was above the critical level of 10% suggested by the Global Action
Plan on HIV Drug Resistance. The distribution of drug resistance mutations was
similar to that seen in previous studies from the region, and further supports
the introduction of integrase inhibitors in first-line treatment in Malawi.
Furthermore, our findings underline the need for continued PDR surveillance
and pharmacovigilance in Sub-Saharan Africa."

For more information on this research see: Pretreatment resistance mutations
and treatment outcomes in adults living with HIV-1: a cohort study in urban
Malawi. _AIDS Research and Therapy_, 2020,17(1):1-7. (AIDS Research and
Therapy - <http://aidsrestherapy.biomedcentral.com>). The publisher for AIDS
Research and Therapy is BMC.

A free version of this journal article is available at
<https://doi.org/10.1186/s12981-020-00282-3>.

Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting F. Neuhann, Heidelberg Institute for Global Health, University
Hospital of Heidelberg. Additional authors for this research include A. de
Forest, E. Heger, A. Nhlema, C. Scheller, R. Kaiser, H. M. Steffen, H. Tweya,
G. Fatkenheuer, S. Phiri.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: University Hospital Heidelberg Researchers Publish New Study Findings on HIV/AIDS (Pretreatment resistance mutations and treatment outcomes in adults living with HIV-1: a cohort study in urban Malawi): Immune System Diseases and Conditions - HIV/AIDS
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at AIDS Daily -- Investigators publish new report on HIV/AIDS. According to news reporting originating from the University Hospital Heidelberg by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “Pre-treatment drug resistance (PDR) among antiretroviral drug-naive people living with HIV (PLHIV) represents an important indicator for the risk of treatment failure and the spread of drug resistant HIV variants. We assessed the prevalence of PDR and treatment outcomes among adults living with HIV-1 in Lilongwe, Malawi.”

Funders for this research include Hector Stiftung, Weinheim , Germany.

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from University Hospital Heidelberg: “We selected 200 participants at random from the Lighthouse Tenofovir Cohort Study (LighTen). Serum samples were drawn prior to treatment initiation in 2014 and 2015, frozen, and later analyzed for the presence of HIV-1 drug resistance mutations. Amplicons were sequenced and interpreted by Stanford HIVdb interpretation algorithm 8.4. We assessed treatment outcomes by evaluating clinical outcome and viral suppression at the end of the follow-up period in October 2019. PDR testing was successful in 197 of 200 samples. The overall NNRTI- PDR prevalence was 13.7% (27/197). The prevalence of intermediate or high level NNRTI- PDR was 11.2% (22/197). The most common mutation was K103N (5.6%, 11/197), followed by Y181C (3.6%, 7/197). In one case, we detected an NRTI resistance mutation (M184V), in combination with multiple NNRTI resistance mutations. All HIV-1 isolates analyzed were of subtype C. Of the 27 patients with NNRTI- PDR, 9 were still alive, on ART, and virally suppressed at the end of follow-up.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “The prevalence of NNRTI- PDR was above the critical level of 10% suggested by the Global Action Plan on HIV Drug Resistance. The distribution of drug resistance mutations was similar to that seen in previous studies from the region, and further supports the introduction of integrase inhibitors in first-line treatment in Malawi. Furthermore, our findings underline the need for continued PDR surveillance and pharmacovigilance in Sub-Saharan Africa.”

For more information on this research see: Pretreatment resistance mutations and treatment outcomes in adults living with HIV-1: a cohort study in urban Malawi. AIDS Research and Therapy, 2020,17(1):1-7. (AIDS Research and Therapy - http://aidsrestherapy.biomedcentral.com). The publisher for AIDS Research and Therapy is BMC.

A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1186/s12981-020-00282-3.

Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting F. Neuhann, Heidelberg Institute for Global Health, University Hospital of Heidelberg. Additional authors for this research include A. de Forest, E. Heger, A. Nhlema, C. Scheller, R. Kaiser, H. M. Steffen, H. Tweya, G. Fatkenheuer, S. Phiri.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
